edge: Donnie Darko is the first feature-length script written by Richard Kelly in 1998.

The time of year influenced Richard Kelly to set the film around Halloween.

Kelly grew up in Midlothian, Virginia, where a local woman called Grandma Death would stand by the road and constantly open and close her mailbox.
Kelly incorporated the moment he almost ran over a homeless person while driving into the narrative.
Kelly had arguments with his school teachers over the curriculum.
Kelly incorporated his personal experiences with sleepwalking into the narrative.
Kelly was unsure whether Frank originated from a dream or his longtime interest in the animal novel Watership Down by Richard Adams.
The novel Graham Greene was to be taught in Karen's English class after the school had censored it from her curriculum.

The word 'fuck-ass', used in the Darko family dinner scene, was something that two of Kelly's film school friends used during their occasional exchange of insults. Frank was initially going to be a rabbit because of Kelly's longtime interest in Watership Down by Richard Adams.
Kelly knew that the film's complicated story would be difficult to pitch to producers without a script, so he had producers read it first before discussing it with them further.

Kelly recalled 1999 being a year of 'meeting after meeting', all of which ended in rejection, and at this point declared the film 'dead'.
McKittrick said Donnie Darko was 'the challenging script in town that everybody wanted to make, but was too afraid'.

Mark Wahlberg was approached to play Donnie, but he insisted that he should play Donnie with a lisp.

Kelly wanted Frank to be 'disturbing and animalistic'. This description indicates a relation between the character Frank and his intended portrayal as unsettling and reminiscent of animals.

Kelly insisted that Frank's face had to 'disturb people and create an intense response with the audience'. This relationship illustrates how Frank's appearance is intended to have a profound effect on viewers.

Kelly wanted Frank's voice to sound as if he was speaking through liquid and 'has the power of the ocean'. This connection indicates how the character's vocal delivery is meant to evoke an aquatic force.

Kelly recalled several people showing him drawings of what they thought Frank should look like, describing them 'like an Easter bunny'. This link portrays the conceptual association between an Easter bunny and Kelly's initial ideas for Frank's appearance.
This link showcases how the novel Watership Down served as an influence on the creation of Frank's costume and mask design.

Kelly chose to portray Donnie challenging the educational system through the pupils wearing school uniforms.
Kelly convinced Steven Poster, cinematographer for Someone to Watch Over Me (1987), to accept the job for a reduced fee.
Kelly's connection with Panavision allowed Poster to shoot with an unprecedented amount of filming equipment from them at a reduced price.
Kelly showed the crew scenes from Peggy Sue Got Married (1986) for its 'idealised ... burnished nostalgia' during night time shots.
The polished cinematography in Donnie Darko 'creates a feeling of hyper-reality, suggesting that all is not what it seems.'

node_2: the film was publicized at the sundance film festival as being the first to feature significant digital effects.
edge: This film, which received recognition at the Sundance Film Festival, is known for featuring innovative and groundbreaking digital effects.

node_2: donnie and frank in his bathroom
edge: In this scene from the film, a water barrier separates Donnie and Frank in the bathroom. This visual effect serves to further the story by creating a physical and metaphorical divide between these two characters.

The liquid spears that emerge from people's torsos in the film are not only visually striking but also serve a symbolic purpose. They can be interpreted as a representation of a character's psyche or as an illustration of the metaphysical idea of predestination, suggesting that these characters are being guided by some unseen force.
The liquid spears in this film bear a striking resemblance to the water tentacle seen in The Abyss. This visual reference adds an extra layer of meaning and depth to the scene.

node_2: liquid spears first appear when donnie is watching a football game on television
edge: The use of this visual motif during a football game not only ties into the film's overall themes but also adds a playful and ironic twist to the scene.

The inspiration for the school flooding in this film can be traced back to a surreal photomontage by Scott Mutter, featuring a giant escalator descending into a rough sea. This visual reference adds an extra layer of meaning and depth to the scene, as it connects the film's themes to those explored in other artistic works.
The majority of the filming for 'Donnie Darko' was completed in Long Beach, California in July and August 2000.
Director Richard Kelly wanted to portray a strong suburban feel for the film and that is why most of the filming was done in Long Beach.
The golf course scenes for 'Donnie Darko' were filmed at Virginia Country Club.
The school scenes for 'Donnie Darko' were shot at Loyola High School.

composed by San Diego musician and songwriter Michael Andrews. Kelly knew that the film's limited budget prevented him from hiring either "Thomas Newman or Danny Elfman" to compose the score for the film, so he decided to look for a composer who happens to be someone "very young, hungry, and really talented". Andrews was recommended by Juvonen's brother, Jim.
Musician and songwriter Michael Andrews is from San Diego.

Kelly made a promise to Sam Bauer that he would edit his first feature film when he had the opportunity, but Pandora Cinema disagreed with the choice initially. Kelly recalled he and McKittrick had to "fight like hell" to get Bauer onboard, and eventually Pandora agreed.

node_2: "under the milky way" by the church
edge: "Under the Milky Way" by The Church is played after Donnie and Gretchen emerge from his bedroom during the party.
"Love Will Tear Us Apart" by Joy Division also appears in the film diegetically during the party and shots of Donnie and Gretchen upstairs.

In the director's cut, the music in the opening sequence is replaced by "Never Tear Us Apart" by INXS; "Under the Milky Way" is moved to the scene of Donnie and Eddie driving home from Donnie's meeting with his therapist;
The film's end sequence features a piano-driven cover of "Mad World" by English new wave group Tears for Fears, sung by American musician Gary Jules
